content: Comcast uses yahoo these days. What provider is the second you are adding. If it is also a yahoo one, clear the cache and cookies in settings before moving forward. Yahoo reuse existing cookies that can cause issues.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Try this; it preserves your whole existing setup.

1. Copy TB files from the old PC

- launch TB on the old PC

- go to TB menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information

- click the Application Basics > Profile Folder 'Open Folder' button

- the profile folder will open

- navigate three levels up to the AppData\Roaming folder

- close TB

- copy the AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird folder to a flash drive

---

2. Paste the copied TB files to the new PC

- open the AppData\Roaming folder on the new PC like you did above

- delete the Thunderbird folder

- replace it with the Thunderbird folder from the flash drive

- launch TB
creator: siffemoz

content: IMAP syncs from the server. I suggest you restore that inbox to Local Folders and then COPY (not move) to the actual inbox

content:
Presumably you're using the TB ESR version. The 'Reset Folder Order' option has only been added in TB142. https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/142.0/releasenotes/

So you can wait for the next ESR version (TB153 ESR) to be released in July 2026. Or you could give the Release version a shot (currently TB147). It can be downloaded at https://www.thunderbird.net/thunderbird/all/

Also see https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-release

Alternatively you may search for an add-on which allows to sort folders. https://addons.thunderbird.net/thunderbird/
creator: christ1

content:
You could create a filter in Thunderbird to delete everything from hotmail.com. However, that would also delete messages from legitimate hotmail.com senders. Fighting spam with static filters is futile. It is therefore recommended to use the TB built-in spam controls. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages

Also, check what spam protection capabilities your email provider offers. Using filters on your email providers server could prevent spam messages to even reach your computer. Depending on your account type you may need to check for false positives on the server though.
creator: christ1

Windows safe mode disables anti-virus software. This is a troubleshooting step, not a solution.

content:
Instructions are here:

https://posteo.de/en/help/how-do-i-set-up-posteo-in-an-email-client-pop3-imap-and-smtp

Your issue is probably caused by using the normal account password instead of the app password required by Posteo.
creator: sfhowes

content: Thanks for responding -- Posteo says that their configurations are automatic for Thunderbird specifically and has a separate instruction list for Thunderbird. However, due to your advice I've created an app password in Posteo, but don't know how to use that in Thunderbird. There's no "app password" option on the drop down menu.
creator: srnordgren

content: THANK YOU -- I realized it was called "encrypted password" and that setting worked.
creator: srnordgren

content: Just to be clear, as I understand Posteo's instructions, the authentication method for the incoming and outgoing should be 'normal password', not 'encrypted password', as the connection is already encrypted (SSL/TLS security). But wherever a password is required in TB, the app password created on the Posteo site must be entered instead of the account password.
creator: sfhowes

content:
That domain appears to be hosted by Google, so click on manual config. and try these settings:

imap.gmail.com, 993, SSL/TLS, OAuth2, email address

smtp.gmail.com, 465, SSL/TLS, OAuth2, email address

content: - First, to unthread an EXISTING folder, click View>sort by and click the unthreaded option. Do this for all existing folders. - to eliminate the need for this for future folders, see settings>appearance where you can set default for FUTURE folders
